Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
RT @RisingFlameNow : Disabled people menstruate too. ü©∏

On #MenstrualHygieneDay, we demand more focus on #access to bathroom & hygiene facilities for disabled menstruators.

Inaccessible bathrooms, along with shame + stigma around menstruation are big barriers to getting proper menstrual care! (1/2) https://t.co/SXlgImKQwT
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
RT @RisingFlameNow : Let's talk about #a11y and digital #accessibility this week! üó£Ô∏èüó£Ô∏èüó£Ô∏è

What are you doing to make your *aesthetic* Instagram (or Facebook, or Twitter, or.. dare we say, LinkedIn?) feed more accessible to disabled folx?

Prioritise digital well-being with us ‚ù§Ô∏è #AccessIsJoy [1/2] https://t.co/YzmqisUr29
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
What's even the purpose of calling us #Divyang when we can't use our divine powers to bring the temperature down. ‚òπÔ∏è
#DisabledLife #DelhiWeather #CenturySoon
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @ChhaviLeekha @mishra_abhi @IndiGo6E @JM_Scindia @DGCAIndia @PMOIndia You should invest a lot more on disability sensitization and training of all your staff so that the next time if it happens (God forbid), you would use 'passengers with disabilities' instead of 'specially-abled passengers'.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: So grateful to have my piece published on Dislang Mag! ‚ù§Ô∏è Head on to the tweet to read! https://t.co/VQ2rpms8JA
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @abhishekanicca @armanaly @nipunmalhotra @drsitu @JoChopra Sure! Got one in June last year. I'll be happy to help! Please DM. :)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @TheSafecityApp @elsamariedsilva @hkearl @chaitanyamukund @chalkbackorg @catcallsofnyc_ @supreetksingh @StopStHarassmnt A3. The larger issue is that women with disabilities are still not given the agency to understand that they have undergone abuse. The fact that 'they're at least being helped' or 'we're thinking too much' is what is given primary importance!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @chaitanyamukund @TheSafecityApp @elsamariedsilva @catcallsofnyc_ @StopStHarassmnt @hkearl @supreetksingh @chalkbackorg Exactly! In fact, whenever we have to rely on strangers for help, we become a little more susceptible to physical abuse and harassment. Irrespective of that, psychological trauma remains.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
RT @RisingFlameNow : For #WorldHealthMonth, equitable + accessible vaccination is on our agenda ‚¨áÔ∏è [Thread]

#Disability and #Gender have both been axes of #vaccine discrimination. Disabled women have faced the brunt of its exclusion. (@KavyaMukhija on @FeminismInIndia) [1/4]

https://t.co/e5JcDZ6Zgw
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @varungrover @fayedsouza @TheQuint @FeminismInIndia @WireDisability @DisabRights_Ind @drag_org @NDRNadvocates @DisabilityIndia
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @MSJEGOI @PMOIndia @Drvirendrakum13 @PMO_NaMo @MSJE_AIC @access_shivani @indiaaccessible @INOXMovies @inoxairproducts @INOXCVA @fromaloktandon @JainSiddharth_
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @ndtv @ShahbazAnsar_ @ScoopWhoop @ThePrintIndia @thewire_in @htTweets @htcity @abhishekanicca @RisingFlameNow @ncpedp_india @chronicpainind @YouthKiAwaaz @CNNnews18 @BBCWorld @BBCHindi @newslaundry @ZeeNews @JagranNews @airnewsalerts @ABPNews @LogicalIndians @SheThePeople
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Image Description: Kavya and her sister sitting near the exit of the movie hall. (11/n) https://t.co/pOJDUGDJgF
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Image Description: Kavya being lifted across the stairs by her brothers and the theatre staff. (10/n) https://t.co/ukbK6TQeXz
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Video Description: Kavya's brothers and theatre staff carrying Kavya up the stairs in the movie hall while she's sitting in her wheelchair. (9/n) https://t.co/OblsIZ6Ft2
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: It's high time we make movie halls and public spaces #Accessible and #Inclusive for #PersonsWithDisabilities. The RPwD Act (2016) mandates all public spaces to be accessible within 5 years. It's 2022 and still no #Accessibility! Why? (8/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: My sister and I had to sit there, next to the exit like outsiders, yet again. Later, she and my mother were made to swap their original seats with some generous folks. My cousins sat away from us. Our leisure time didn't turn out the way we thought it would. (7/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Would such treatment be meted out to a non-disabled person? It felt humiliating being lifted inside a full house with all eyes oogling at me. Do I not have basic human dignity? Do #WheelchairUsers not have basic dignity? (6/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: With narrow aisles and staircases, my brothers and the theatre staff had to lift me all the way up to the top row because there was no space elsewhere. This is #Discrimination! When will this stop? Why do persons with disabilities are made to compromise on leisure? (5/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: But persons with disabilities have existed ever since! And even at that time, they made a ramp instead of stairs at the entrance leading to the hall (a great move indeed) but didn't make the theatre accessible from the inside? (4/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: When we spoke to someone from the management, they said that the cinema was built in 2006. Hence, this is all that could have been done. (3/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Here as well there were just seats reserved for persons with disabilities in the bottom-most row. How are we supposed to watch from such a close distance? What sort of inclusion is this? Why this discrimination DESPITE paying in full? (2/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
The #Ableism never stops. The discrimination never stops. Twice in 2 months.

Went to watch The Kashmir Files at @INOXMovies, Satyam Cinema, Nehru Place, New Delhi with my cousins. (1/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
RT @YouthKiAwaaz : "I‚Äôve been living a life where ‚Äòdo it yourself‚Äô was the only way to do things. Call it the greatest form of freedom or subjugation, we‚Äôre called to build the life we want, writes YKA member @KavyaMukhija 
https://t.co/yw66ROAh6s
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Inspired by Megha Rao's poetry - Most Of Us Will Live The DIY Life (n/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
We may be #inspiring & motivating. But at what cost?
The DIY life may be our exclusive effort to overcome discomfort and fatigue; and foster equality (no matter how little), it is not an unbearable, undesirable, unwanted life. It is a good life. A happy life. A proud life. (11/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: It's always like - if you want it, do it yourself. Build a table or an entire world, here you're your own curator, your own architect. I may be a speckle of the 10% of the population of those like me, but I'm invisible. We're invisible. (10/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: #Disability is not a result of personal failure, it is, in fact, a result of systemic breakdown. A breakdown that's been taking place through decades and the brunts of which is being borne by generations. (9/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
The DIY life, though may seem free and dominated by personal will, it is a subtle hint at the invisibility of & disregard for #PwDs. 
While we may love to have things our way, it frustrates us to constantly be on the edge and brainstorm ideas to make our lives easier. (8/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: (This definitely doesn't tone down the struggle we have to put up with.) We often long for external validation of our experiences and thrive when we get one. This is why. (7/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
So it is convenient as well as legit to say that persons with disabilities carry heirlooms of trauma, discrimination, and internalised ableism.
The DIY life has been lived by generations before me. The only difference is theirs are far tougher than mine and ours. (6/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
(We're inspiring, aren't we?) I remember making a device by taping two rulers together to reach the key stand to grab the keys off it.
Our lives do not fit the 'normal'. Hence, the world doesn't see us which is why it is not built to accommodate us. (5/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
Call it the greatest form of freedom or subjugation, we're called to build the life we want.
No one backs us up. For us, saving a few spoons to smile an extra hour calls for a journey down an unexplored alley to figure out a way to save those spoons - Mission I'm Possible. (4/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: For me, and I'm sure for others as well, living a #disabled life has been another rendition of an adventure sponsored by #ableism, perpetuated by stereotypes and supported by inequality. For us, everything is about tests and trials. The life we want isn't out there. (3/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: The realisation hit me when, instead of purchasing a ready-made table on Amazon, I decided to make one myself. The expenses almost equalled that of a new table, yet I invested in my labour, saving myself some of my hard-earned bucks. (But did I really?) (2/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
DIY Life - A #Thread

As I grab everything I need to make a #DIY table, I realise that, as a person with a disability, I've been living a DIY life as well - a life where 'do it yourself' was the only way to do things. (1/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
RT @BehanBox : #Thread | @KavyaMukhija, who has a locomotor #Disability, had to take a week-long sick leave before her class 12 board exam. She had contracted a UTI. This wasn't new to her. Her school did not have disability-friendly washrooms.
https://t.co/IAAFF8LXYx
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: RT @abhishekanicca : Ended up watching Sajan again somehow and can't help but feel it isn't recognized as a quintessential film about disability. And I have decided to take up the matter in my own hands and do a thread about it. 1/n https://t.co/8bXnXM6Z7G
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @PVRSupport So @PVRSupport are you saying that Delhi wasn't on the list of the first 50 cities chosen? That's extremely surprising. Even though I've shared my contact details, I've not heard from anyone yet. Is that how your customer care service functions? I'm appalled.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @armanaly @saysnidhigoyal @Khetarpalabha @mahajan_anubha @drsitu @anitaghai4 @disabledspice @SheThePeople @IndianExpress @SvayamIndia @LogicalIndians
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: ID: A photo of Kavya in the movie theatre. She's sitting near the exit (not visible in the photo) and stairs leading to the next row. (9/9) https://t.co/Xk4LJZ1wRI
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: ID: A screenshot of book my show's PVR Vegas Dwarka theatre layout, showing the seats reserved for wheelchair users/persons with disabilities. (8/n) https://t.co/vo8kfFokzw
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: I spoke to the deputy manager there, after the movie. He apologized and assured that he'd convey it to the committee and make the theatre accessible. I really hope they educate themselves on what exactly is wheelchair accessibility. (7/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: It's frustrating to experience discrimination every single time! This was not the first time I faced this in the theatre. What an irony that this happened on International Wheelchair Day! @_PVRCinemas, you RUINED our family time. (6/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Why am I required to sit away just because I use a wheelchair? What inclusion are we talking about? This is 2022 and we still don't know what wheelchair access is? Why can't I just feel included and welcomed for once? (5/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: What's even the point of claiming wheelchair access when you don't even have proper, dignified seating arrangement!? Why am I required to move out of my chair? Am I not supposed to watch films if I'm a wheelchair user? Why am I made to feel unwelcome every time? (4/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: When I spoke to the deputy manager there, he said that the hall was 'wheelchair accessible' because the wheelchair could enter. What next? Where were wheelchair-users supposed to sit? (3/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: We went there and found that they just had regular seats designated for wheelchairs users. With no option, I had to sit away from my family near the door, like an outsider! (2/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: I went to the movies with my family after ages in Delhi at @_PVRCinemas, Vegas Mall, Sector 14, Dwarka) because I had heard that it was wheelchair accessible and even their page on @bookmyshow said so! (1/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
@RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana Sex and disability is like taking a trip! You're excited to think about what you may find on your way. üòÅ
Also, my life, my choice! üòé
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana Aah! Feels lovely to be able to talk about #love, #disability, #marriage and #desire! #LoveMatters #DilVilPyaarVyaar
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @saysnidhigoyal @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana @imadmantrii ü§≠
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @saysnidhigoyal @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana @imadmantrii Is it also a way to make them fall for you? üòç *wink wink*
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @VinayanaKhurana @lovemattersinfo So true!!! I totally love my body but some days are grey and not red or orange, which I think is okay and perfectly fine! I think it also reinstates that I accept my body and it is this acceptance which making me hate it for a little while. ‚ù§Ô∏è
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @lovemattersinfo @RisingFlameNow @VinayanaKhurana Whenever #wwds reach that age, career suddenly becomes the most important of all! It is often seen that #wwds are forced to 'say yes' to whoever chooses to marry them, even if they don't even know their name yet!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana I was on a dating app once and the experience was just fine. No remarks on my #disability or the redundant suggestions. When I mentioned to a guy that I loved traveling but #inaccessibility becomes a hindrance, he was very open and even mentioned that #accessibility is so imp!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @VinayanaKhurana @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo Also, when we finally accept and love ourselves, snide remarks don't stop! It's as if love, sex, desire is a territory owned by the able-bodied and we are merely the spectators! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§∑
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @VinayanaKhurana @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo I so agree with you! It reminds me of that story in which all the frogs in a well try to pull the one frog down who is trying to get out of that space.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana I think the connection is very innate. Self-love becomes really hard when at every step people around you tell you that you are different and you will be treated like that throughout your life. We are constantly dodging the barriers of ableism in order to fit in!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana @shotofshiva This piece reflects the reality on so many levels! Talking to someone out of sympathy is something that is common to every #PwD. Even when we try to embark on a relationship, our feelings are just shunned away!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana @shotofshiva Exactly! And they tell us (with a caring attitude) to focus on more important things.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana Of course! But loving and being love is also one of them! We have been installed with a loving heart for a reason. Let's use it and spread some love around! üòÅ
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana So, when I'd share that I have a crush on so and so guy, my friends would smile as if I was a child and I didn't know what I was saying. Even though they didn't say anything, their smile said it all - it implied that I was still a kid. It strangled me.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: @RisingFlameNow @lovemattersinfo @VinayanaKhurana Yayyy! So exciteddd!
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
#SeduceSomeoneInFourWords 
Wheelchair users: There is a ramp!

Humour is innate and #PwDs are humourous too (look at me!)
However, let's always respect individuals while making jokes! ^o^

#access #accessibility #disability #wheelchair #disabled #humour
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
Is #IISUniversity proud to see me #graduating, working hard for three long years? I don't think so. 
#disabled #disabled #disabilityeducation #nothingaboutUSwithoutUS #disabledandproud #DisabilityRights #disabilityinclusion 
(9/9) 
Here's this young graduate in #psychology. https://t.co/YwKSemBZ4k
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
I was made to feel #disabled for all the wrong reasons; that my #disability is a hindrance and that my #needs have to be explicitly stated before they can be taken into consideration. 
(8/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
I am as much eligible for an equitable treatment as any other student and in no way should I be asked to compromise just because I'm disabled! 
(7/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
Would it have been different if I was not disabled? Are my parents not guests on this solemn occasion? Would they have made special arrangements if it was a #nondisabled person in my place?

I have #specialneeds as a result of my #disability and I'm fully aware of it. 
(6/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
This is a moment of pride for us but we were disrespected. Rules are rules, I get it; but rules can be modified to take the reasonable needs of #personswithdisabilities into consideration, and respect them. 

(5/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
We were directed to the front gate where we were told to go back - "entry will be permitted'. We went and the loop continued. In the end, my mother had to park the car at the back entrance outside the campus and make me sit on my wheelchair on the unlevelled road. 

(4/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
What I don't understand is why I was not permitted to even park the car in the campus to get down, even though my mom repeatedly assured that she will park the car back out?

(3/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
Having spent three precious years of my life learning in this institution, it was no less than a second home for me. But today, my car was not allowed in the University campus because of the protocol which I totally understand. 
(2/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text:
Attended one of the most momentous days of my life - the Convocation Ceremony. But I was disrespected which left disappointed. 

Read the thread to know why.

(1/n)
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)

Text: Leadership by #PwDs is about breaking barriers, both literally and metaphorically! It is about creating a world that functions on the each person's strengths, keeping the #ableist notion out of context. #WeCanLead #Leadership #LeaderswithDisabilities https://t.co/k2BN686uNT

Text:
RT @Shayonnita15 : Today, I met a woman at a train station. We were standing together on the platform.

We exchanged smiles, and I went back to reading something on my phone.

When I looked up a few moments later, she was still looking at me. I smiled again. She smiled back. We looked away.

1.
Name: Kavya Mukhija (she/her)
